title.narrative: Improved access to health, nutrition and protection services for the most vulnerable people, especially children, women and displaced people along the axes of the target areas

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health, nutrition and child protection assistance to vulnerable communities in Bangui, Kemo, Ouaka, Ouaham and Nana-Mambéré prefectures. This UNICEF project deploys mobile nutrition units; screens children for severe acute malnutrition; admits severely malnourished children to outpatient therapeutic programmes; raises awareness among mothers and caregivers about infant and young child feeding; procures emergency health kits for health facilities; deploys mobile clinics to provide curative and preventive health services; provides psychosocial assistance to crisis-affected children and their caregivers; and reunites unaccompanied and separated children with their families. The health component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 42,500 people, including 1,250 women, 1,250 men, 40,0000 children. The nutrition component provides life-saving assistance to 25,000 children. The child protection component provides life-saving assistance to 9,000 people, including 4,500 women and 4,500 children.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC RAPID RESPONSE DISPLACEMENT 2021

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 100 agents de santé et 200 relais communautaires sont formés sur le dépistage-référence et la prise en charge de la malnutrition aiguë sévère.

CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation (community relays trained on screening, referral and the package of nutrition promotion services)

CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation (health worker trained on integrated protocol for the management of acute malnutrition)
25,000 vulnerable children (13,000 girls and 12,000 boys) affected by the crisis will have access to essential healthcare services
H.1a Number of emergency health kits delivered to healthcare facilities (50 IEHK2017, kit, basic Unit et 10 IEHK 2017, kit, suppl.- 1 medecines received in Bangui)
Number of children in crisis-affected areas who received basic preventive and curative health care
Number of mobile clinics set-up in the targeted crisis-affected areas
Number of monthly supervision and monitoring visits to health facilities in target areas
4,500 children aged 6-59 months with SAM are timely screened and referred to immediately receive quality treatment for severe acute malnutrition
Death cure rate according to SPHERE standards (gender-disaggregated data) and the national protocol for the management of acute malnutrition
Defaulter rate according to SPHERE standards (gender-disaggregated data) and the national protocol for the management of acute malnutrition
N.3a Number of severely acutely malnourished people admitted to therapeutic feeding programme
N.3b Percentage of people who were admitted for SAM treatment who recovered

Front line child protection services are available and strengthened to address the protection needs of de 40,000 vulnerable children (22,000 boys et 18,700 girls) affected by the post-electoral violence in CAR
CP.1 Number of unaccompanied or separated children identified and assisted, including family tracing and reunification (reunified with their families or accessing family based alternative care)
H.9 Number of people provided with mental health and pyscho-social support services (children and caregivers)
Number of Community- Based Child Protection Networks (CBCPNs) set-up for prevention and response to child protection concerns
Number of children released from armed groups and other vulnerable children at risk of recruitment who have access to income-generating activities, formal education and vocational training
Number of children survivors of GBV accessing GBV prevention and response services
PS.1b Number of safe spaces and/or centres constructed or rehabilitated (Child friendly Spaces in emergency affected communities)

The prevention of malnutrition in emergency situations is reinforced with 4,500 children aged 6 to 59 months receiving vitamin A supplementation, 3,653 children aged 12 to 59 months being dewormed and 4,500 pregnant and breastfeeding women being sensitized on good practices for infant and young child feeding in emergency situations
N.5 Number of people receiving vitamins and/or micronutrient supplements (children aged 6-59 months receiving vitamin A supplementation)

N.6 Number of people benefitting training and/or community awareness sessions on infant and young child feeding in emergencies (targeted pregnant and lactating women reached in the community, receiving counseling for the stimulation, promotion and protection of breastfeeding and appropriate infant and young child feeding practices.)
Number of children aged 12-59 months dewormed
Number of home visits performed by the community relays
